author: BVM Sportsdesk
title: Women's Basketball Defeated 53-40 at Vermont
text:
Women‚Äôs Basketball Defeated 53-40 at Vermont
Vermont secured a decisive 53-40 victory over Binghamton in an America East women's basketball matchup. Anna Olson led the Catamounts with 15 points and seven rebounds, supported by Bella Vito's double-double of 12 points and 10 rebounds. Despite a strong rebounding effort from Binghamton, they struggled offensively, shooting only 29.3% from the field. Vermont asserted dominance early, establishing a solid lead that Binghamton could not overcome in the second half.
- Anna Olson scored 15 points, with 7 rebounds and 3 assists.
- Binghamton out-rebounded Vermont 43-31 despite a shooting percentage of just 29.3%.
Binghamton's rebounding advantage (43-31) indicates dominance on the boards, but their shooting struggles undermined any potential for victory. While they showcased moments of resilience, offensive efficiency remains a significant concern.
State of Play- Vermont remains a strong contender with a conference record of 7-1.
- Binghamton's struggles continue, now standing at 3-5 in conference play.
Binghamton will look to bounce back when they host UAlbany on Saturday at 2 p.m. A victory will be crucial for regaining momentum in their season.
Bottom LineBinghamton must improve their shooting consistency to capitalize on their rebounding strengths. Effective offensive strategies will be key for upcoming games, especially against conference rivals like UAlbany.
Read more at Binghamton University Athletics

title: Pron√≥stico en Santiago del Estero para este viernes: lluvias intensas y vientos de hasta 50 km\/h
text:
La temperatura oscilar√° entre 19¬∞C y 32¬∞C, con mejoras parciales hacia la tarde y noche.
Pron√≥stico en Santiago del Estero para este viernes: lluvias intensas y vientos de hasta 50 km/h Pron√≥stico en Santiago del Estero para este viernes: lluvias intensas y vientos de hasta 50 km/h
El Servicio Meteorol√≥gico Nacional emiti√≥ un alerta amarillo para Santiago del Estero por la posibilidad de tormentas fuertes durante la ma√±ana de este viernes 13 de diciembre. Las condiciones clim√°ticas incluyen lluvias intensas, r√°fagas de viento y elevada humedad, con un 70% de probabilidades de tormentas significativas.
La jornada comenz√≥ con una temperatura de 20¬∞C, cielo cubierto y tormentas d√©biles, acompa√±adas de una humedad del 95% y vientos del sur a 20 km/h. La visibilidad se mantiene en 8 kil√≥metros.
Tambi√©n te puede interesar:
Por la ma√±ana se esperan tormentas fuertes, con r√°fagas de viento que podr√≠an alcanzar los 50 km/h. La probabilidad de lluvias significativas se sit√∫a en un 70%. Por la tarde: Las condiciones mejorar√°n parcialmente, con cielo parcialmente nublado y vientos del sur a una velocidad de 31 km/h.
Finalmente, por la noche, el cielo continuar√° parcialmente nublado, con vientos moderados provenientes del este a 12 km/h.

author: Frank Schwab, Yahoo Sports
title: NFL Winners and Losers: In post-Tom Brady world, Buccaneers still win NFC South title ‚Äì Boston 25 News
text:
By Frank Schwab, Yahoo Sports January 07, 2024 at 4:09 pm EST
Expand
Tampa Bay Buccaneers v Carolina Panthers CHARLOTTE, NORTH CAROLINA - JANUARY 07: Devin White #45 of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers reacts to a tackle during the first quarter against the Carolina Panthers at Bank of America Stadium on January 07, 2024 in Charlotte, North Carolina. (Photo by Grant Halverson/Getty Images) (Grant Halverson/Getty Images)
By Frank Schwab, Yahoo Sports January 07, 2024 at 4:09 pm EST The Tampa Bay Buccaneers' highest paid player, in terms of the salary cap, retired about a year ago. Tom Brady's $35.1 million cap hit accounted for almost $11.5 million more than any other player on the roster.
It wasn't ideal, but whatever. Brady was great for the Buccaneers and brought the franchise a Super Bowl title. It was worth a terrible, rebuilding season while the Bucs got their salary cap back in order.
Then a funny thing happened. The Buccaneers were pretty good down the stretch. Baker Mayfield, signed to a bargain one-year deal as he tried to revive his career, played well. Players from the Super Bowl season like receivers Mike Evans and Chris Godwin and linebacker Lavonte David were still productive. Young players like running back Rachaad White, defensive tackle Vita Vea and safety Antoine Winfield Jr. kept getting better. Coach Todd Bowles, who was probably was on the hot seat during a 4-7 start, brought it all together late in the season.
Winning the 2023 NFC South wasn't an incredibly high bar to cross, and Sunday's game was really ugly for Tampa's offense, but the Buccaneers will happily take their playoff spot. The Buccaneers beat the Carolina Panthers 9-0 to clinch an NFC South championship. Three field goals held up. The Buccaneers would have been eliminated with a loss, and they did enough to win.
Sunday was a slog against a two-win Panthers team. The offense struggled to do much. But the defense was very good, getting the shutout. The defensive performance included a phenomenal play from one of Tampa's superstars.
The Panthers were about to take a 7-0 lead when receiver D.J. Chark was running down the sideline. But right before Chark got in, Winfield came in with a clutch hit and knocked the ball loose. The Bucs recovered in the end zone. Instead of a Panthers touchdown, the Bucs had the ball back. It was a massive, season-changing play.
. @AntoineWJr11 knocked it out for a touchback üëè
üì∫: #TBvsCAR on FOX
üì±: Stream on #NFLPlus https://t.co/X0vcyHUoyR pic.twitter.com/s8rVqVD4AV
‚Äî NFL (@NFL) January 7, 2024 When the Panthers were driving in the fourth quarter, the Bucs got another key turnovers. Carolina had a touchdown taken off the board due to an illegal formation penalty, then Joe Tryon-Shoyinka strip-sacked Bryce Young and Tampa Bay recovered.
The Buccaneers ran out the clock after that. It wasn't a pretty win, but nothing has been pretty in the NFC South all season. And nobody will remember how Tampa Bay won the division in Week 18, only that the Bucs won the division and are going to the playoffs.
When Brady retired, the Bucs were supposed to fade for a couple seasons. There were plenty of jokes about tanking for Caleb Williams when Tampa Bay announced Mayfield as the starting QB. The New Orleans Saints and Atlanta Falcons had better rosters on paper than the Bucs, and that's a good reason the head coaches from those teams are in trouble after Tampa Bay won the division. The Buccaneers weren't supposed to be in the playoffs, not in this season when Brady was taking up more than 15% of their salary cap. Mayfield and Bowles might have saved their careers with a surprising playoff berth. It wasn't the prettiest division title for Tampa Bay, but it's one worth celebrating.
Here are the rest of the winners and losers from the early games in Week 18:
WINNERS Derek Carr: At least Carr ended the season on a positive note, individually speaking.
The New Orleans Saints weren't getting much out of Carr for most of the season, especially for the $150 million deal they signed him to. But Carr played arguably his two best games to end the regular season. Carr threw four touchdowns and the Saints beat the Atlanta Falcons 48-17. New Orleans rubbed it in a bit by faking a kneeldown and scoring in the final two minutes, and Falcons coach Arthur Smith wasn't happy about that.
The Saints didn't win the division because the Buccaneers handled business against the Panthers, but the win kept the Saints alive for a wild-card spot through the afternoon games.
Carr's 4th TD pass of the game
A.T.'s 2nd TD grab
have a day, fellas #Saints | üì∫: CBS pic.twitter.com/I0jDL4B7y5
‚Äî New Orleans Saints (@Saints) January 7, 2024 New Orleans can feel a little better about Carr, who threw two touchdowns in a win over the Bucs in Week 17. It took a while to get going. But it's not like the Saints can move on from Carr's massive deal after one season, so it's not too bad to end the season with a couple good games from their quarterback.
Jake Browning: Browning doesn't know the next time he'll get a chance to start in the NFL. So he took advantage of his last start this season in place of Joe Burrow.
Facing a Cleveland Browns team that had the No. 5 seed wrapped up and sat practically every key player, the Cincinnati Bengals rolled to a 31-14 win. Browning threw three touchdowns and looked pretty good once again. The Bengals had such a big lead, Browning was taken out of the game early in the fourth quarter.
Browning did fairly well in his time replacing Burrow. He put enough on tape that he should be considered a priority backup or perhaps even a bridge quarterback for a needy team going forward. He had one last chance to make an impression on Sunday, and made the most of it.
LOSERS Doug Pederson: Trevor Lawrence will get a lot of heat for a miserable Jacksonville Jaguars loss on Sunday. Lawrence played poorly, the Jaguars lost 28-20 to the Tennessee Titans and that allowed the Houston Texans to win the AFC South. The Jaguars were eliminated with the loss. The Pittsburgh Steelers got a wild-card spot with the Jaguars loss.
A lot will fall on Lawrence and some of that is fair, but he was playing through multiple injuries. He clearly wasn't the same after a high ankle sprain suffered against the Bengals in Week 13. While Lawrence still is responsible for some of his key mistakes, like missing a wide-open Calvin Ridley deep downfield for a potential touchdown in the final two minutes, Pederson can't be let off the hook.
TREVOR LAWRENCE AND CALVIN RIDLEY ALMOST HAD A TD N pic.twitter.com/2cjz6lwiZT
‚Äî Mr Matthew CFB (@MrMatthew_CFB) January 7, 2024 The Jaguars were clearly the most talented team in the division and they're going home. They looked unprepared to play a Titans team that had been eliminated long ago and had to turn to Ryan Tannehill at quarterback with Will Levis injured. The Titans controlled most of the game. The Jaguars were up against the ropes in the third quarter, trailing 28-13, when Pederson decided against a field goal on fourth-and-7, he went for it and Lawrence completed a pass well short of the first down.
Later, when the Jaguars had goal-to-go, trailing 28-20, they ran a terrible rollout with Lawrence on third down that he threw away and then he tried to extend the ball over the line on fourth down but was short. Jacksonville had one last chance after that but Lawrence missed Ridley downfield on second down and then threw incomplete on third and fourth down.
The Jaguars shrunk in a big moment. Lawrence's critics will be out after the loss. Pederson's critics should be too.
Offensive football in New England: As the field turned from green to white in New England under the heavy snow, it became tougher for the New York Jets and New England Patriots to move the ball.
And those two teams can't move the ball in perfect conditions.
If Sunday was Bill Belichick's last game as Patriots coach, it was an ugly way to go out. The Jets won 17-3, putting it away on a Breece Hall touchdown in the final two minutes, the first touchdown of the game. Snow games are fun, but not when both teams are completely inept on offense.
One play summed up the fun. The Patriots had a fourth-and-1 near midfield in the fourth quarter, trailing 6-3. For some inexplicable reason, New England decided to pass it even though Bailey Zappe was 8 of 22 for 65 yards at that point. Zappe threw short, it was predictably knocked incomplete and the Jets took over. The Jets ended up with the win, their first against the Patriots since 2015.
A miserable season for New England ended with a rough loss. Then the real drama started with the future of their great coach.
Minnesota Vikings: Last season, the Vikings deserved worse. This season, they deserved better.
The good luck the Vikings received last season when they won the NFC North reversed this season. Minnesota stayed in the playoff mix until the season finale, but ultimately the Vikings couldn't overcome their injuries, especially at quarterback. The Detroit Lions didn't rest starters even though they had only a small shot to move up from the No. 3 to No. 2 seed in the NFC (a decision that could haunt coach Dan Campbell after tight end Sam LaPorta suffered a knee injury), and the Lions ended the Vikings season. Detroit won 30-20. There will be questions about the Lions secondary after Nick Mullens threw for 396 yards, but Mullens also had a couple of costly picks in the loss.
The Vikings have an interesting offseason coming up. Kirk Cousins is a free agent and he's coming off a torn Achilles. Minnesota has a quarterback situation to figure out. After they settle QB, they'll hope for a lot better luck next season.

author: Daily Sun
title: The setting sun bids farewell to the eventful 2023. The River Meghna embraces the twilight as the sun dips below the horizon on the last day of the year, casting vibrant colours across its flowing water. The picture was taken from the bank of the River Meghna in Ashuganj, Brahmanbaria. -Focus bangla

author: News Staff
title: chevron-right
text: In a release from St. Vincent de Paul (SVdP), the organization says they are working to respond to the needs of the "most vulnerable neighbors" during this cold weather. Here are the list of services they are offering as well as updates for what their crews are doing/in need of: The Eugene Service Station is offering a warming center and day shelter with no one being turned away. The Dusk to Dawn congregate shelter for unhoused adults has temporarily moved to the Lane County Fairgrounds. The First Place Annex Night Shelter for unhoused families is at capacity. They have sent as many families as possible to local motels that are now at capacity as well. We are looking for another partner hotel and sending families to Egan Warming Centers locations for the time being. We are sending crews out to check on our various sites and shuttle people to Egan locations as needed. Blankets, hats, gloves, and warming items have been collected at 888 Garfield today. We will accept similar donations at the Chad Drive location on Monday. Stores are closed but SVdP says that any closure puts a strain on funding for their programs. The fact that we‚Äôve also had to close our stores for several days, and lose that primary source of operational revenue, is placing a real strain on the organization, and we‚Äôre asking the public for help. If you are able to leave your home safely, they are asking for donations of blankets, hats, and gloves tomorrow at their administrative offices on 2890 Chad Drive in Eugene. They will also be accepting donations of blankets, pillows, eggs, coffee, sugar, butter, and milk tomorrow at First Place Family Center (4060 W. Amazon Drive in Eugene) as well as shelf-stable food at the fairgrounds. Finally, they are in need of volunteers at the Egan Warming Centers, particularly for the 2 a.m. to 6 a.m. shifts. Drivers are also needed to shuttle between the Eugene Service Station and Fairgrounds between 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers can [sign up on their website](https://www.svdp.us/services/shelter-assistance/egan-warming-centers/) or by [emailing Tim Black](tim.black@svdp.us). Donations can also be made online at the [St. Vincent de Paul website](https://www.svdp.us/) by clicking the donate button. We will have more as we receive updates from SVdP during this winter weather emergency.
